citation.article-title: Lactococcus fujiensis sp. nov., a lactic acid bacterium isolated from vegetable matter
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Lactococcus fujiensis sp. nov.
Lactococcus fujiensis (fu.ji.en′sis N.L. masc. adj. fujiensis of or belonging to Mount Fuji, where the species was isolated).

Cells are Gram-reaction-positive, catalase-negative, non-sporulating, non-motile, coccoid or ovoid-shaped, facultatively anaerobic and homofermentative, growing well anaerobically on MRS agar at 30 °C, and occur singly, in pairs, or as short chains.
Pinpoint colonies on MRS agar plates are white, opaque and<0.4 mm in diameter.
Grows at pH 4, at 35 °C and in 3 % (w/v) NaCl but not at pH 3.5, at 40 °C or in 6.5 % (w/v) NaCl.
Acid is produced from ribose, mannitol, starch and β-gentiobiose but not from d-xylose or amygdalin.
The major fatty acids are C18 : 1ω9c, C16 : 0, C14 : 0 and summed feature 10 (C18 : 1ω11c/ω9t/ω6t).
The DNA G+C content is 42.1–42.5 mol%, as determined by HPLC.

The type strain, NJ 317T ( = JCM 16395T), was isolated from a sample of Chinese cabbage (Brassica rapa L. var. glabra Regel) taken from a local commercial vegetable food factory in Fujinomiya (near Mount Fuji), Shizuoka, Japan.
